httpserver

Class MessageHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • httpserver.HTTPHandler
      • httpserver.MessageHandler

  • public class MessageHandler
extends HTTPHandler
    A MessageHandler is a simple handler that sends a simple text message to the client. A MessageHandler solves the problem of sending a simple message back to the client regardless of the request, without requiring developers to create a new HTTPHandler.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      MessageHandler(int code, java.lang.String message)
      Create a message handler All it does is call message(code, message).
      MessageHandler(java.lang.String message)
      Create a message handler, with the HTTP status set to 200 Calls message(200, message).

    • Constructor Detail

      • MessageHandler

        public MessageHandler(int code,
              java.lang.String message)
               throws HTTPException
        Create a message handler All it does is call message(code, message).
        Parameters:
        request - The associated HTTPRequest. Required by all Handlers.
        code - An HTTP status code to be used with the attached message.
        message - A simple text message to be sent to the client.
        Throws:
        HTTPException
        See Also:
        HTTPHandler#message, HTTPRequest

      • MessageHandler

        public MessageHandler(java.lang.String message)
               throws HTTPException
        Create a message handler, with the HTTP status set to 200 Calls message(200, message).
        Parameters:
        message - A simple text message to be sent to the client with the HTTP status code of 200.
        Throws:
        HTTPException
        See Also:
        HTTPHandler#message, HTTPRequest

    • Method Detail

      • handle

        public void handle(HTTPRequest req,
          HTTPResponse resp)
        Description copied from class: HTTPHandler
        Where the Handler handles the information given from the request and based off of the paths specified in the Handler.

        This can be overridden for more fine-grained handling. As is, it uses the data behind the addGET, addPOST, and addDELETE methods for determining the correct action to take.

        If there is not exact match, the `*` path is used. If you don't have a `*` catchall route, a 501 (Not implemented) is sent to the client.

        Overrides:
        handle in class HTTPHandler
        Parameters:
        req - The incoming HTTPRequest.
        resp - The outgoing HTTPResponse, waiting to be filled by an HTTPHandler.
        See Also:
        HTTPHandler.addGET(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), HTTPHandler.addPOST(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), HTTPHandler.addDELETE(java.lang.String, java.lang.String), HTTPResponse.NOT_A_METHOD_ERROR
